items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high and rising. 15mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech today. From 12:00 12/03/2024, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and affect gardens of properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 14:00 12/03/2024, minor flood impacts could also affect gardens on Station Road, and Church Road, Hellingly. From 17:00 12/03/2024, minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and fields in Alfriston. The rain should clear by 14:00 12/03/2024. Only isolated showers are then forecast Wednesday to Saturday afternoon 16/03/2024. The river should begin to fall by 23:00 12/03/2024 in Hellingly. In Alfriston, river levels might not fall until 08:00 13/03/2024. River levels could end up similar to early March. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 13/03/2024.

items.message: The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high and rising. 10mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill today. From 12:00 on 12/03/2024, minor flooding could affect fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and gardens of a small number of properties in Crowhurst. Potentially including riverside properties on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house, and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. From 23:00 12/03/2024, water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. The rain should clear by 14:00 12/03/2024. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday through to Saturday afternoon 16/03/2024. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 12/03/2024 in Crowhurst. In Bulverhythe, river levels might not fall until 08:00 on 13/03/2024 and could remain higher than normal all week. River levels are not currently expected to rise as high as late February. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 13/03/2024.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising. 15mm of rain has been recorded at Ardingly on Tuesday. From 17:00 on 12/03/2024, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens near Freshfield Mill Farm on Sloop Lane. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge could also be affected by flooding. From 19:00 on 12/03/2024, Barcombe Mills Road is likely to be affected by flood water. Flooding could approach the Anchor Inn, and perhaps gardens of properties at Barcombe Mills. Only isolated showers are forecast until Saturday afternoon. The river should begin to fall by 18:00 on 12/03/2024 near Ardingly, but not until 06:00 on 13/03/2024 in Barcombe, where river levels could be higher than normal until Thursday (14/03/2024). River levels could peak similar to 02/03/2024. Some roads may become impassable, including Barcombe Mills Road. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 on 13/03/2024.

items.message: The River Ouse is high, and expected to rise this Tuesday evening. 20mm of rain has been recorded at Ardingly. There is still uncertainty, but from 23:00 on 12/03/2024, minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads, the Pells and Railway Lane areas, and gardens of Riverdale and Malling Deanery near Willeys Bridge, Lewes. items.description: River Thames at Thames Ditton Island

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 
River levels are rising on the River Thames at Thames Ditton Island as a result of high tides. The forecast for today is for light rainfall with heavier showers in some localised areas. The forecast for tomorrow is dry.
Tide 1 has exceeded the original forecast predictions and is still rising. The updated forecast levels will reach a height between 5.5m and 5.75m.
Tide 2 (5:15 am on 13 March) will reach a height between 5.45m and 5.75m. 
Tide 3 (5:45pm 13 March) will reach a height between 5.4m and 5.7m.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/03/24 or as the situation changes.
